moves.1. c4 e5 2. d3 Nf6 3. a3: a suggestion of Bent Larsen, playing a Najdorf with the white pieces!
moves.3... Nc6 4. Nc3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 N: intending after 8 ... exd4 9 cxd4 Bishop moves the cautious 10 e3 (not 10 e4 overextending the pawn!)
moves.9. Ng5 Be7:
I spent a lot of time analyzing 9 ... Nxd4 10 cxd4 Bxd4 finally I found 11 Qb3! Qf6 
12 Nxe4 now 12 ... Qf5? 13 Qa4+! winning.
this is good.  the doubled pawns made it more difficult for white to realize his advantage.
moves.14. e5 Bxg3 15. hxg3 O-O-O 16. O-O f6 17: hereabouts we enter a phase of careful maneuvering by white.
moves.22. Be2: an option was to play 22 Rxf5 but things get complicated after 22 ... g6
seeming the only way to make progress and setting a trap into which black falls
moves.25... Bxg4 26. Rxf8+ Rxf8 27. Bxe7 Rh8 2: this allows white to win rapidly.  29 ... Qf5 offered more resistance
moves.30. e6: much stronger than 30 Qf3 which would have also probably won.
moves.30... Qd6 31. Qe5: intending after 31 ... Qc6 to set up a decisive advance of the pawn with e7 and Rf1
moves.31... Qxe5 32. dxe5: now after 32 ... Rh5 33 Rd1!! Rxg5 34 e7 Rxe5 35 Rd8+ Kb7 36 e8Q wins
